body.name: The Warsaw Orphan
body.description: Instant New York Times best seller!Inspired by the real-life heroine who saved thousands of Jewish children during WWII, The Warsaw Orphan is Kelly Rimmer’s most anticipated novel since her best-selling sensation, The Things We Cannot Say. “Gripping... This one easily stands on its own.” (Publishers Weekly)“Heart-stopping.” (Lisa Wingate, number-one New York Times best-seling author)“A surefire hit.” (Kristin Harmel, number-one New York Times best-selling author)In the spring of 1942, young Elzbieta Rabinek is aware of the swiftly growing discord just beyond the courtyard of her comfortable Warsaw home. She has no fondness for the Germans who patrol her streets and impose their curfews, but has never given much thought to what goes on behind the walls that contain her Jewish neighbors. She knows all too well about German brutality - and that it's the reason she must conceal her true identity. But in befriending Sara, a nurse who shares her apartment floor, Elzbieta makes a discovery that propels her into a dangerous world of deception and heroism.Using Sara's credentials to smuggle children out of the ghetto brings Elzbieta face-to-face with the reality of the war behind its walls, and to the plight of the Gorka family, who must make the impossible decision to give up their newborn daughter or watch her starve. For Roman Gorka, this final injustice stirs him to rebellion with a zeal not even his newfound love for Elzbieta can suppress. But his recklessness brings unwanted attention to Sara's cause, unwittingly putting Elzbieta and her family in harm's way until one violent act threatens to destroy their chance at freedom forever. From Nazi occupation to the threat of a communist regime, The Warsaw Orphan is the unforgettable story of Elzbieta and Roman's perilous attempt to reclaim the love and life they once knew. Read more

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 30, 2024
reviews.reviewTitle: 5.0 out of 5 stars So Many Twists and Turns - Like Real Life
reviews.reviewText: I will admit that the intensity of this book, at times, had me putting it down to process what I was reading. Truly I wish that schools in the US would use historical fiction like this in their English Lit classes. It might be the only way for the newer generations to understand what really happened during World War Two. Thank you for touching my heart and reminding me to be thankful for the sacrifices of so many in occupied countries.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on December 21, 2023
reviews.reviewTitle: 4.0 out of 5 stars Fascinating Historical Fiction
reviews.reviewText: Set first in the Warsaw Ghetto, then in the Soviet occupation and finally in the Soviet take over of Poland, this novel follows a young girl as she becomes a young woman. It highlights the ability of the human spirit to survive in the most inhuman moments of history. Worth reading.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on February 1, 2024
reviews.reviewTitle: 5.0 out of 5 stars Excellent story, captivating and so real!
reviews.reviewText: I read a lot of historical accounts of holocaust survivors. This is one of the best. By taking parts of real people's stories the author has created characters that live & breathe. And while there is a lot of heartache for the characters, the story itself inspires everyone to be the best human being you can be.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on February 6, 2024
reviews.reviewText: The characters were vivid, as well as the setting. Parts were hard to read although if we cannot learn from the past, we are doomed to repeat history.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 10, 2024
reviews.reviewTitle: 5.0 out of 5 stars THE WARSAW ORPHAN
reviews.reviewText: The Warsaw Orphan, from the very beginning I was spell bound. The Characters were as if I knew them. Roman and Emelia were two young people struggling from love ,to the Germans eradicating their precious family. They scavenged for food, rations, helping others and just staying alive. The support of Emilia’s family and Roman’s special friends helped, however, the occupation of the Soviets made survival in Poland one terror after another.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on December 11, 2023
reviews.reviewText: The only thing I did not like, is the ending, just so abrupt, I very much dislike books with this type of ending.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 18, 2024
reviews.reviewText: This book explored a side of WWII of which I had little knowledge. Several twists and turns keep me very curious and engaged. The end was a little predictable but wrapped up the characters in a tidy way. It was a good ending - the way it should have. I highly recommend!

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on December 28, 2023
reviews.reviewTitle: 5.0 out of 5 stars A compelling read
reviews.reviewText: An emotional and compelling tale of another look at the everyday heroes of World War 2. The characters drew me into the story as they struggled to survive and yet reach out to those in need, namely the orphans and children whose lives were in danger. This was a sometimes difficult read, but also an inspirational read and the characters stayed with me, even after I put the book down.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on August 21, 2021
reviews.reviewText: I loved this book.It is written in a way that is easy to follow and although I found that the characters lacked depth at times, the story is compelling and I read it in a couple of days, really enjoying it.

Kelly Rimmer has done it again! One of the queen's of historical fiction has written an amazing, heart wrenching novel! I cried more than once while reading this, as I do in most of her historical fiction.It is emotional, poignant, heartbreaking and hopeful – capturing the harshness in the war years for many, including the Polish. First with the arrival of the Germans, and then the Soviets control... They suffered terribly – The Warsaw Orphan shows the reader all the emotions of the time – and with a filling of hope along the way.The Things We Cannot Say was one of my favourite books of 2019, so I was touched by the connection between that novel and this one. This one also depicts the horrors of the Holocaust with emphasis on the Warsaw Ghetto, the Polish Uprising and the strength and bravery of the resistance. This story pulls no punches. It's one of constant starvation, brutality, death, and destruction.It’s not easy to read- from the beginning it is heart breaking stories, reflective of the Holocaust. There’s starvation, an overcrowded ghetto, and a poor nine year old boy whose unpaid job it is to help the police pick up the dead bodies in the street... Kelly Rimmer has done an amazing job at capturing the details of the day to day life in the ghetto, the growing fear and understanding of what was to come with the deportations to the death camps.
I bought this book as a birthday gift. The recipient enjoyed reading it.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on September 28, 2021
reviews.reviewText: The most poignant, heart rending story. Extremely well written and researched. Difficult to read in places which is to be expected. Thoroughly recommend it
